coredata.dc:title: Crashworthiness characteristics investigation of silk/epoxy composite square tubes
coredata.dc:creator: Oshkovr, S.A.
Eshkoor, R.A.
Taher, S.T.
Ariffin, A.K.
Azhari, C.H.
coredata.dc:description: AbstractThis research concentrates on the evaluation of crashworthiness characteristics of natural silk/epoxy composite square tubes energy-absorbers. Composite laminate specimens were subjected to static axial compression load and experimental evaluation of the energy absorption capability of silk/epoxy composite. Specimens were in the form of square cross-sections with the dimension of 80mm×80mm and a radius curvature of 5mm. The variables in the experiment were the length of the tubes built 50mm, 80mm and 120mm. Meanwhile, the thickness of the walls, consisting of laminates of silk/epoxy of 12, 24 and 30 plies, correspond to equivalent wall thickness of 1.7mm, 3.4mm and 4.2mm, respectively. The parameters measured were the total absorbed energy (Etotal), and the crash force efficiency (CFE). Etotal is the measure of the amount of energy that the structure can withstand without failure and thus is a measure of its strength, while CFE gives a quantitative indication of the mode of failure of the composites. The mode of failure was observed using photography.

B. Mechanical properties

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Axial compression test of square tube with 50mm length and 30 layers silk/epoxy: (a) photographs of different steps of compression test and (b) combined diagram of load P, and crash energy absorption E, variation during the test. The sequential number of each picture marks the point of the two curves corresponding to the photographs.

Axial compression test of square tube with 80mm length and 30 silk/epoxy layers: (a) photographs of different steps of compression test and (b) combined diagram of load P, and crash energy absorption E, variation during the test. The sequential number of each picture marks the point of the two curves corresponding to the photographs.

Axial compression test of square tube with 120mm length and 30 silk/epoxy layers: (a) photographs of different steps of compression test and (b) combined diagram of load P, and crash energy absorption E, variation during the test. The sequential number of each picture marks the point of the two curves corresponding to the photographs.
Peak and average load characteristics for short length (a), medium length (b) and long length (c) composite square tubes (error bars denote standard deviations).
Total absorbed crash energy E for short length (a), medium length (b) and long length (c) square tube (error bars denote standard deviations).
Specific energy, SAE and maximum compressive strength, σmax for short length (a), medium length (b) and long length (c) specimen (error bars indicate standard deviations).
Crush force efficiency CFE, and stroke efficiency SE, characteristics for short length (a), medium length (b) and long length (c) square tubes (error bars denote standard deviations).

head.ce:title: Crashworthiness characteristics investigation of silk/epoxy composite square tubes

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Mechanical & Materials Engineering, University Kebangsaan, 43600 Bangi, Malaysia

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: This research concentrates on the evaluation of crashworthiness characteristics of natural silk/epoxy composite square tubes energy-absorbers. Composite laminate specimens were subjected to static axial compression load and experimental evaluation of the energy absorption capability of silk/epoxy composite. Specimens were in the form of square cross-sections with the dimension of 80mm×80mm and a radius curvature of 5mm. The variables in the experiment were the length of the tubes built 50mm, 80mm and 120mm. Meanwhile, the thickness of the walls, consisting of laminates of silk/epoxy of 12, 24 and 30 plies, correspond to equivalent wall thickness of 1.7mm, 3.4mm and 4.2mm, respectively. The parameters measured were the total absorbed energy (Etotal), and the crash force efficiency (CFE). Etotal is the measure of the amount of energy that the structure can withstand without failure and thus is a measure of its strength, while CFE gives a quantitative indication of the mode of failure of the composites. The mode of failure was observed using photography.

ce:section.ce:para: Recently together with structural efficiency, passenger safety is also an important issue in application of material to transportation industries. Hence, the crashworthiness parameters are introducing to predict the capability of structure to prevent the massive damage and protect the passenger in the event of a crash. Crashworthiness parameters for various thin-walled tubes made from metal or fibre/resin composites in different geometries have been studied. A critical difference of tubular composites failure modes compared with metallic is the brittle collapse. In addition, in composites, tubular failure modes are involved with micro-cracking development, delamination, fibre breakage, etc., instead of plastic deformation. Implementation of composite materials in the field of crashworthiness is attributed to Hull, who in 80s and 90s of the last century studied extensively the crushing behaviour of fibre reinforced composite material. He found that the composite materials absorbed high energy in the face of the fracture surface energy mechanism rather than plastic deformation as observed for metals [1]. This observation has inspired others to further investigation about crashworthiness characteristics of composite materials. Studies have examined the axial crushing behaviour of fibre-reinforced tubes [2], fibreglass tubes [3,4], PVC tubes [5] and carbon fibre reinforced plastic (CFRP) tubes [6].

In real applications, for example, in automobiles, the square tubes are not only energy-absorbing members, but also serve as load-carrying structures. Furthermore, axially crushed thin-walled square tubes have been widely used as energy absorbers because of their high specific energy absorption capacity and long stroke [7]. On the other hand, based on some studies remarkably few works has been done on natural composite materials in the automotive industry during the last century hence limited researches for thin shell structures made of natural fibres have been published [8]. Nowadays, natural fibres are receiving more interest due to increase attention to use ecofriendly materials.

This research focused on using silk due to its superior strength, durability, high failure elongation, higher specific energy absorption also it is notable that silk has better resistance to moisture when compared to other natural fibres. Previous paper [8] presented results for 12 layers silk/epoxy composite square tubes also a comparison table of mechanical properties of some natural fibres including silk and synthetic fibres. In order to improve the silk/epoxy square tubes crashworthiness parameters, in the current work crushing response of silk/epoxy composite in the form of 24 and 30 layers of silk/epoxy square tubes experimentally investigated. It analyses the crushing load–displacement profile of silk/epoxy square tubes determine the crashworthiness parameters and overall energy absorption on composite tubes. The findings might be used as the basis of design guidelines for using silk in crashworthy systems and safety applications.

Silk/epoxy square tubes made of silk woven fabric in weft (90°) and wrap (0°) direction and weft fibre direction was parallel to the tubes’ axis. Specimens were compressed in INSTRON MTS 810 universal testing machines utilised with 250kN load capacity. Load–displacement curves obtained from quasi-static compression test for silk/epoxy square tubes is presented in the following sections. Results are divided into three groups namely short length, medium length and long length according to their lengths (50mm, 80mm and 120mm). Meanwhile, each section presents crushing history as load–displacement curves, which are describing the different type of square tubes used for the tests according to their number of silk/epoxy layers (12, 24 and 30 layers). For easy comparison in the current paper, final results for 12 layers [8] are added to the results for 24 and 30 silk/epoxy laminates square tubes.

(Figs. 1–3) consist of two parts. Part (a) depicts photographs of different stages of the tests, and part (b) indicates the load–displacement curve which presenting the energy-absorbing capability of tubes. The sequential number of each picture marks the point of the two curves corresponding to the photographs. Results regarding the morphology of the tubes in steps of the tests and information obtained from load displacement curves have been discussed as following.

Load–displacement curves of silk/epoxy composite square tubes resulted from compression test with 50mm length and different numbers of silk/epoxy layers (24 and 30 layers) presented from Figs. 1–3. Combined diagrams of the load–displacement curve and energy are indicated from Figs. 1b–3b. According to the load–displacement curves, tubes behaving linearly in the beginning of the test. Fig. 1b presents the load drops down by compression of the square tube. This remarkable decrease in load presents mid length buckling with failure starting in the composite square tube from half of the length of the tube. Photographs present the steps of deformation in the tubes and are taken at various steps of the compression during the testing of the square tubes.

Silk/epoxy tubes were found to crush in modes slightly different than those observed in synthetic composite structures. For brittle composite materials such as glass and carbon composites based on epoxy resin, the crushing process is a cyclic process of interlaminar cracks propagating between layers in the crushed region of the tube forming lamina bundles [9]. For the metallic tubes, the crushing process is a process of plastic deformation. Silk/epoxy composite square tubes in compression test presented a ductile deformation without debris splitting after being crushed.

In general, the failure modes observed during compression tests were unstable local buckling and mid length buckling and affected by the geometry of composite square tubes in terms of a number of silk/epoxy laminates and lengths of composite square tubes. According to previous researches the nonlinear energy absorption response suggests that care must be taken in selecting specimen geometry for energy absorption characterisation studies [11].

In the initial stages of compression, load–displacement curves showed a significant drop in load after reaching the peak load. High peak crush failure load leads to a catastrophic failure mechanism at initial failure crush stage, which results in low crush force efficiency (CFE) at post-crush stage as well as unstable load–displacement behaviour. However, significant energy can also be absorbed when structural elements catastrophically fail [2].

Utilising compression test photographs helped to understand the modes of failure. Tubes with 24 and 30 number of silk/epoxy composite laminates square tubes in all lengths (50mm, 80mm and 120mm) exhibited mid length buckling, which was failure initiated at the mid of the tube length which then proceed to overall tube buckling followed by catastrophic failure. This failure clearly has been shown in Figs. 1–3. In the other word, mid length buckling in the compressed specimens is featured by ductile fracture and unstable collapse of the compressed tube, which commences with a circumferential fracture of the composite laminate at a distance approximately equal to its half the tube length this phenomena is clearly presented in Fig. 2a. This figure performs a significant reduction of the compressive load after reaching the peak load followed by tube catastrophic failure.

Some of the silk/epoxy composite tubes, for example, in Figs. 1b and 2b diagrams demonstrate first and second peak loads. These tubes performed significant reduction of the compressive load immediately after the load–displacement curve reached the maximum load in the region of the crush zone. Away from this zone rest length of the tube has remained with less damaged, and almost it looks like as a shorter square tube. Hence with continuing the deformation second peak load was observed when the load reached the second maximum, thereafter load dropped to the lower value until the compaction zone.

In Figs. 4–7, the crash load/energy absorption characteristics of the tested composite square tubes namely peak compressive load (Pmax), average compressive load (p¯), absorbed crash energy (E), specific absorption energy (SAE), maximum compressive strength (σmax), crush force efficiency (CFE) and stroke efficiency (SE) are presented. Error bars denote the standard deviations of specimens with same geometrical characteristics. Errors indicate the variety of data for specimens in the compression tests. In order to have a general graphical comparison of tubes according to their length, two sets of crashworthiness characters were combined in each diagram.

Each load–displacement curve shows the history of crushing for related tube. Crushing started at a critical value which is called peak load, and then the load traveled along the tube. As it has been reported before by some researchers, during catastrophic failure, the peak load is remarkably high and drops off quickly, so the average load is low [10]. Information from the load displacement curves in Figs. 1b–3b directly showed the maximum loads (Pmax) in silk/epoxy composite tubes during compression tests. Meanwhile, average compressive load (p¯) for each tube was calculated from the load–displacement curve related to the tube. Results have been indicated in Fig. 4 for silk/epoxy composite tubes with different length and thickness.

Increase peak load and average load associated with the rising number of composite laminates in Fig. 4a and b. It clearly indicated that, number of composite plies in the tube wall of the tested specimens influence significantly on peak load value. It is notable in Fig. 4a there is a significant higher value of peak load and average load in tubes with 30 plies of silk/epoxy laminates to compare with 24 plies of silk/epoxy laminates. This difference is slightly in Fig 4b, and finally in Fig. 4c peak load and average load are almost constant in 24 and 30 silk/epoxy composite plies. This constant amount is presenting the critical thickness of silk/epoxy composite square tube, which is 24 layers of silk/epoxy laminates in long length tubes (120mm).

As conclusion, results showed specimens with higher numbers of plies and shorter length performed more resistance in compression test with performing higher value of peak and average load. Meanwhile, results presented the critical thickness in long length tubes with 24 layers of silk/epoxy composite. It is proven by previous researches, mentioned that peak load is depended on the geometric and material characteristics of the tested specimen [1,2].

The value of energy absorption capability of a structure is depended on the area under the load–displacement curve. Consequently, square tubes with higher value of crushing load showed the higher value of energy absorption. Fig. 5c presents the critical thickness in the square composite tubes which is indicating by a constant value of energy absorption in long length square tubes with 24 and 30 layers plies of silk/epoxy laminates.

Total absorbed crash energy (E) is depicted in Fig. 5 for short, medium and long lengths square tubes. The effect of decreasing thickness in energy absorption reduction calculated in the form of a percentage. Obtained results indicated that the energy absorption capability decreased (13.1%) when wall thickness reduced from 4.2mm (30 layers silk/epoxy) to 3.4mm (24 layers silk/epoxy) and decreased (76.5%) when wall thickness reduced from 4.2mm to 1.7mm (12 layers silk/epoxy). These figures also show that while the highest length (120mm) decreased to 80mm and 50mm, energy absorption capability reduced 35.6% and 37.6%, respectively.

Results remarked that the capability of energy absorption of the silk/epoxy square tube is depended on the geometry of tubes. Tubes with higher length and thickness are able to absorb more energy, which is due to absorbing more energy by their long length until the end of crushing. This phenomenon is the same for tubes with the higher number of laminate plies resulted in higher value of absorbing energy caused by resistance of more layers. Overall length and thickness tubes effect on the load hence peak load and average load. In the meantime, the energy is the area under the load–deformation curve hence it is depended on peak and average load. The following figure also performs the critical thickness in tested silk/epoxy square tube composite.

Fig. 6 indicates the specific absorbed energy SAE and maximum compressive strength σmax values according to specimen length. Specific energy absorption of the tubes is defined as the absorbed energy per unit mass of tube and maximum compressive strength of the tubes is the maximum carried load to the cross sectional area of the specimen. This figure revealed that the length of specimens has the reverse effect on the specific energy and maximum strength. Results cleared increasing the number of plies has a direct effect on the increase the maximum compressive strength and specific energy. As it mentioned earlier maximum strength is depend on the peak load to the cross section area of the specimen. Specific energy in short and mid lengths tubes increase with the increase the number of layers of specimens. On the contrary, the specific energy for long length tube with 30 layers decrease due to increase of the weight of specimens.

Another important measure of crush performance is the crush force efficiency, which is defined as the ratio of the mean crush average load to the initial crush failure load. In order to evaluate the crashworthiness of energy absorber device, attention should be directed to its crush force efficiency (CFE) the stroke efficiency (SE).

The diagrams depicted in Fig. 7 include the crush force efficiency (CFE) and the stroke efficiency (SE). As mentioned crush force efficiency (CFE) is an important crushing characteristic of the load–displacement curve. In silk/epoxy composite square tubes once the crush started load dropped significantly and collapse continues with low value load. The ratio of average load and peak load is a considerable value to presents the failure mechanism of composite namely catastrophic or progressive failure.

Small values of CFE proved that catastrophic failure happened in all silk/epoxy composite tubes. Catastrophic failure is affected by geometry of a specimen. Data comparison between diagrams in Fig. 7 performed long length tubes (120mm) obtained slightly higher value of crush force efficiency. These figures also show silk/epoxy tubes’ stroke efficiency. The desire energy absorber device has crushable structures, which can be defined as SE.

Silk/epoxy has high elongation at failure which causes high energy absorption capability. Moreover low density of silk decreases weight of tubes and improves the specific energy absorption. But comparison between silk/epoxy and similar carbon/epoxy tubes previously reported by Mamalis et al. [11] shows much higher specific energy absorption by carbon/epoxy tubes. This fact is due to the lower Young’s modulus of silk, which results decreasing in buckling load in the silk/epoxy composite tubes. This phenomenon is more significant when length of tubes increases or thickness decreases. To avoid early failure in the tube, controlling the buckling using different means are suggested, e.g., using a hybrid of silk and carbon fibres based composite, implement thick sandwich instead of thin laminate walls and controlling the buckling load using a proper trigger mechanism.

This study focused on natural silk/epoxy square tubes energy absorber. Square tubes made of a different number of silk/epoxy layers, which are 12, 24 and 30 layers. According to the tests, crashworthiness parameters were defined and analysed. In the axial compression tests, all the specimens exhibited catastrophic failure. Specimens failed with mid length buckling, which was failure initiated at the mid of the tubes which then proceed to be overall. Results showed that the highest values of Etotal (1.03kJ) were obtained for the specimens with 30 silk/epoxy laminates and 120mm depth, while the maximum value for CFE (0.30) was obtained in the specimen with 12 layer silk/epoxy laminates and 120mm length. Meanwhile, a remarkable increase in peak load was performed from square tubes with 24 and 30 layers silk/epoxy composite laminate to compare with square tubes with 12 layers silk/epoxy composite in short length tubes. Increasing the length of tubes showed the critical thickness in a long length tube which is 24 layers of silk/epoxy composite, which caused a constant peak and average load in square tubes with 24 and 30 plies of silk/epoxy laminates.
